channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Why Amy Klobuchar just wrote 600 pages on antitrust
item.description: “Monopolies tend to have a lot of control, not just over consumers, but also over politics.”

item.title: Review: The role-playing game’s afoot in charming black comedy Murder Bury Win
item.description: It’s not an instant classic like Clue, but it’s fun, very solid indie fare.

item.title: Rivian’s electric truck features include air compressor and AC outlets
item.description: It’s got storage compartments galore, plus an extending truck bed.

item.title: Apple brass discussed disclosing 128-million iPhone hack, then decided not to
item.description: Emails entered into Epic Games lawsuit show execs contradicting Apple talking points.

item.title: It began as an AI-fueled dungeon game. Then it got much darker
item.description: AI algorithm created disturbing stories, including sex scenes involving children.

item.title: Windows 10 “Sun Valley” will do away with Windows 95 era icons
item.description: The results are more subtle than you might expect from a 25+ year visual update.

item.title: Sony faces lawsuit over alleged “monopoly pricing” of PlayStation downloads
item.description: Proposed class action says Sony’s moves have increased prices for PlayStation games.

item.title: 96% of US users opt out of app tracking in iOS 14.5, analytics find
item.description: Some of the first data on user behavior exceeds advertisers' worst fears.

item.title: Ajit Pai promised cheaper Internet—real prices rose 19 percent instead
item.description: Home-Internet prices rose four times faster than inflation in Trump era.

item.title: Tesla Autopilot director contradicts Musk’s self-driving timeline
item.description: Musk described full autonomy as “basically a solved problem” in 2016.

item.title: Google wants people to use 2FA, so it’s just going to turn it on for them
item.description: Non-tech-savvy users always use the defaults, and the default will soon be 2FA.

item.title: Facebook and Big Pharma exploited disease “awareness” for personalized marketing
item.description: Visiting medical sites, patient support groups, and more feed the algorithm.

item.title: Did our ancestors kill all the island megafauna?
item.description: Study adds data to a long-running argument.

item.title: IBM creates the world’s first 2 nm chip
item.description: IBM’s new 2 nm process offers transistor density similar to TSMC’s next-gen 3 nm.

item.title: Unsolved mysteries of the Warhammer 40k universe with loremaster Dan Abnett
item.description: Best-selling author goes deep—like, real deep—on wild and crazy Warhammer questions.

item.title: Why hasn’t Waymo expanded its driverless service? Here’s my theory
item.description: Suburban ride-hailing is a lousy business to be in.

item.title: What cats’ love of boxes and squares can tell us about their visual perception
item.description: “Vision has evolved to answer questions having to do with boundaries and contours.”

item.title: 9,000 fliers may have had reused swabs jammed up their noses in Indonesia
item.description: Five workers were arrested for washing and reusing cotton swabs for testing.

item.title: Paramount+ lifts ViacomCBS to 36 million subs, will stream sci-fi movie Infinite
item.description: Streaming service commits to one original movie every week.

item.title: World of Warcraft: Burning Crusade re-returns on June 1, requires “cloning”
item.description: If you’re already in WoW Classic, you have a decision to make starting May 18.

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: New iPad Pro, Amazon devices, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on wireless headphones and lots of video games.

item.title: Biggest ISPs paid for 8.5 million fake FCC comments opposing net neutrality
item.description: ISP-funded astroturfing used millions of real names and faked consent records.

item.title: Sea level rise uncertainties: Why all eyes are on Antarctica
item.description: Latest models project a bumpy road with big risks.

item.title: The Google Assistant is now a Google messaging service
item.description: “Broadcast” now works on speakers, displays, and phones for your whole family.

item.title: US physics lab Fermilab exposes proprietary data for all to see
item.description: Exposed systems paved way for researchers to access code, messages, passwords, and more.

item.title: China’s carbon pollution now surpasses all developed countries combined
item.description: As China’s coal-reliant economy has boomed, so, too, have its emissions.

item.title: Stranger Things hints at return of Eleven’s “Papa” in new teaser
item.description: Matthew Modine, who played Dr. Martin Brenner, was spotted on set earlier this year.

item.title: Earliest known burial in Africa is that of a small, fragile child
item.description: Early humans in Kenya buried a dead child with tremendous care 78,000 years ago.

item.title: Nintendo warns global chip shortage to hit Switch production
item.description: Nintendo follows rival Sony in saying supply crunch threatens console sales.

item.title: NASCAR ditches decades of tradition for its Next Gen race car
item.description: Cup cars will run centerlock wheels, sequential transmissions, and flat floors.

item.title: World waits to see where a Chinese booster will come down
item.description: The 20-ton booster is big enough that some parts are likely to reach the ground.

item.title: Fix for critical Qualcomm chip flaw is making its way to Android devices
item.description: Higher-end devices made by Google, Samsung, LG, Xiaomi, and OnePlus are affected.

item.title: Severe vulnerabilities in Dell firmware update driver found and fixed
item.description: Dell firmware update driver 2.3 can be exploited to gain kernel-level privilege.

item.title: Twitter’s latest robo-nag will flag “harmful” language before you post
item.description: Follows Twitter’s effort to make you read the news before you share it.

item.title: SpaceX successfully lands a Starship test flight
item.description: Given that it’s meant to be the basis for a lunar lander, landing it is good.

item.title: Google tries to resurrect Android tablets with “Entertainment Space”
item.description: Google brings a TV-like media-aggregation interface to tablet home screens.

item.title: Biden backs plan to accelerate vaccine production by waiving patents
item.description: Experts disagree on whether patents are a bottleneck for vaccine production.

item.title: At trial, Epic and Apple squeeze Microsoft over Xbox, xCloud restrictions
item.description: Questions over Xbox restrictions, xCloud’s iOS struggles serve as comparison points.

item.title: Study: Using Apple’s Night Shift to improve your sleep? Don’t bother
item.description: The test was done with iPhones, but many gadgets have a similar feature.

item.title: Data leak makes Peloton’s Horrible, No-Good, Really Bad Day even worse
item.description: Faulty API let anyone grab users’ private data, including weight and gender.

item.title: Appeals court allows parents to sue Snap over 100 mph car crash
item.description: The parents argued a Snapchat filter encouraged their boys to drive recklessly.

item.title: AMD’s upcoming flagship GPUs should be 3x faster than RX 6900XT
item.description: If the rumors can be believed, GPU performance will triple sometime next year.

item.title: Chip shortage continues, US asks Taiwan to prioritize automakers
item.description: Ford, Renault, and Stellantis warn that Q2 production will be heavily affected.

item.title: Blue Origin isn’t pricing its first launch seat—it’s auctioning it
item.description: Jeff Bezos' rocket co. targets July 20 for its first crewed launch.

item.title: Mighty morphin’ flat-packed pasta takes on 3D shapes as it cooks
item.description: New approach could lead to more sustainable packaging, transportation, and storage.

item.title: Hands-on: We hammered Plume’s newest Superpod design with all-new Wi-Fi testing
item.description: If you can stomach a subscription, Plume’s Superpods offer unmatched performance.

item.title: YouTube’s TikTok clone, “Shorts,” is out of beta and open for all US users
item.description: Shorts are coming, and the feature is getting a premium spot in the YouTube app.

item.title: Peloton recalls treadmills after 6-year-old’s death, CEO admits “mistake”
item.description: Consumer Product Safety Commission said recall decision took “intense negotiation."

item.title: Plug in a PS5 keyboard to access Returnal’s hidden “debug mode” codes
item.description: But some players fear Housemarque may patch out the codes soon.

item.title: Starlink can serve 500,000 users easily, several million “more of a challenge”
item.description: The “only limitation is high density of users in urban areas,” Musk said.

item.title: Resident Evil Village review: Apparently, good horror takes more than a village
item.description: We had high hopes for “RE4 + RE7,” but pumped-up combat isn’t enough for this sequel.

item.title: Tesla loses huge customer for emissions credits in Europe and the US
item.description: Stellantis paid Tesla $2.4 billion for credits between 2019-2021.

item.title: Facebook Oversight Board upholds ban on former President Trump
item.description: While the ban was permissible, its open-ended nature was not.

item.title: AirTag review: They work great—maybe a little too great
item.description: Apple made the most privacy-friendly tracker, but that’s not saying much.

item.title: “Agricomb” is the perfect tool for measuring gases from cow burps
item.description: More precise measurements could help boost yields and enable design of cleaner farms.

item.title: Biden shifts strategy as national vaccination rate continues to slow
item.description: Vaccinations have been steadily declining since mid-April.

item.title: NASA has selected its deep space hardware—now comes the fun part
item.description: “This isn’t a dream any more.”

item.title: Netflix IT exec forced employees to use products from vendors that bribed him
item.description: Jury finds ex-Netflix VP guilty of awarding tech contracts in exchange for bribes.

item.title: The new abnormal is warming up the US government’s new climate norms
item.description: The US’s expected weather are based on a 30-year average, updated once a decade.

item.title: Epic thinks EGS could make up 35-50% of the PC gaming market by 2024
item.description: Epic v. Apple gives us our deepest look yet into the economics of Epic’s storefront.

item.title: New Spectre attack once again sends Intel and AMD scrambling for a fix
item.description: A new transient execution variant is the first exploit micro-ops caches.

item.title: Today’s best deals: $40 Nintendo Switch games, Kindle Paperwhite, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on true wireless earbuds and Garmin running watches.

item.title: Frontier exits bankruptcy, claims it will double fiber-to-the-home footprint
item.description: Frontier plans 3 million new fiber lines—but 8M others would be stuck on copper.

item.title: Review: Shadow and Bone is a worthy adaptation of the Grishaverse novels
item.description: If Cursed had a love child with The X-Men—who was then raised by Doctor Zhivago.

item.title: Researchers raise bats in helium-rich air to check how they sense sound
item.description: Bats seem to have an innate sense of the speed of sound—and can’t adjust it.

item.title: Goodbye again, Flash—Microsoft makes removal from Windows 10 mandatory
item.description: Windows “Update for Removal of Adobe Flash Player” becomes mandatory this July.

item.title: How the next Patent Office director could shape the patent system
item.description: Obama created “death squads” for bad patents—Trump’s nominees curtailed them.

item.title: 4,700 Amazon employees had unauthorized access to private seller data
item.description: Shoddy security allowed various employees to use info to their advantage.

item.title: Stadia’s VP and head of product leaves Google
item.description: Google’s embattled Stadia division loses one of its highest-profile executives.

item.title: Starship flight attempt for Tuesday afternoon is scrubbed [Updated]
item.description: After four failures, SpaceX is really hoping to stick the landing this time.

item.title: Porsche and Penske: Two of racing’s most famous names join forces again
item.description: The pair will run teams in WEC and IMSA, and there will be customer cars, too.

item.title: The Martian’s Andy Weir is back to form with Project Hail Mary
item.description: Some quick and spoiler-free thoughts on the new book, out today.
